types

namespace types

Hash_Set_Iterator

template<typename T> struct Hash_Set_Iterator

An iterator for Hash_Set (and Hash_Map).  It’s a forward iterator, you can only go one direction and without offsets.

Constructs an iterator from <chain>** and “current” <chain>*.  Used by the find function.

++

Hash_Set_Iterator operator++(int)

Moves on to the next chain and returns an iterator to the current chain (before incrementing).  Postfix version.

template<typename U> friend bool operator!=(const Hash_Set_Iterator &a,

Hash_Set_Const_Iterator

template<typename T> struct Hash_Set_Const_Iterator: Hash_Set_Iterator<T>

Const version of Hash_Set_Iterator.  Inherits from Hash_Set_Iterator.  Besides its own typedefs, it provides a constructor allowing to create it from a standard Hash_Set_Iterator and overloads for the * and -> operators.

Hash_Set

template<typename T> struct Hash_Set

An efficient associative container implementation using a hash table.  It can be used for efficient key-value associations that are unordered.

Anything can be used as either key or value, ranging from POD types through objects to pointers.

You should, however, never store a pointer inside the container unless you manage it elsewhere to prevent memory leaks (you can however store it in reference counted container, <shared_ptr>).

This structure represents a “set”, where a key value is the same as data value.  It serves as a base for actual map, where key and data are different.  It simply inherits and makes use of <pair>.

If you need ordered storage with bidirectional and reverse iterators, you can use set, which is implemented using binary tree.  It has, however, worse insertion / lookup time complexity.  It can also use any type as a key, while this can use only those which are supported by the hash function.

typedef types::Hash_Set<int> myset;
myset test;
// these two ways are equivalent in function, the
// second one is better if the element doesn't exist.
test[5] = 5;
test.insert(5);

// searching
printf("%i\n", test[5]);
// this will not fail - it'll insert a value, so it'll print 10.
printf("%i\n", test[10]);

// iteration
for (myset::cit it = test.begin(); it != test.end(); ++it)
    printf("%i\n", *it);

// erasing, will delete the data
test.erase(5);

// retrieving the set length
printf("%i\n", test.length());

// will clear the set - also done
// automatically in the destructor
test.clear();

Functions
Hash_SetConstructs an empty Hash_Set.
Hash_SetClears up the Hash_Set, deletes the table and the nil chain, so it doesn’t leak.
lengthReturns the set length (the amount of chains with actual data).
is_emptyReturns true if the set contains no chains (except nil) and false otherwise.

Types

it

An iterator typedef for standard, non-const iterator.

cit

An iterator typedef for const iterator.

Functions

Hash_Set

Constructs an empty Hash_Set.  You can provide the size it’ll use for the table (bigger size means less chaining, the default of 1 << 10 should be fine in most of cases).

Hash_Set

~Hash_Set()

Clears up the Hash_Set, deletes the table and the nil chain, so it doesn’t leak.

length

size_t length() const

Returns the set length (the amount of chains with actual data).

is_empty

bool is_empty() const

Returns true if the set contains no chains (except nil) and false otherwise.

begin

it begin()

Returns an iterator to the first chain.

begin

cit begin() const

Returns a const iterator to the first chain.

end

it end()

Returns an iterator to the last chain.

end

cit end() const

Returns a const iterator to the last chain.

insert

T& insert(const T &data)

Inserts the given data into the table.

clear

void clear()

Clears up the Hash_Set and makes the length zero.  Doesn’t delete the table.

erase

template<typename U> void erase(const U &data)

Erases a chain with a given key from the set.

find

it find(const T &data)

Returns an iterator to a chain that belongs to a given key.  There is also a const version that returns a const iterator (non-modifiable).

find

cit find(const T &data) const

Const version of find.  The result cannot be modified.

An efficient associative container implementation using a hash table.
template<typename T, typename U> struct Hash_Map: Hash_Set<Pair<T, U> >
See Hash_Set.

An efficient associative container implementation using AA tree (an enhancement to the red-black tree algorithm, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AA_tree).
